dt-option.name: stateSaveCallback
dt-option.summary: Callback that defines how the table state is stored and where.

type.parameter: Data to save. The data comes from `-init stateSaveParams`

dt-option.description:
DataTables saves the state of the table (paging, filtering etc) and by default it will use HTML5's `localStorage` to save the state into. When the `-init stateSave` option is enabled, this callback method allows you to change where the state is saved (for example you might wish to use a server-side database or cookies).
The data given to the function is an object which has the following structure:
```js { "time": {number} // Time stamp of when the object was created "start": {number} // Display start point "length": {number} // Page length "order": {array} // 2D array of column ordering information (see `order` option) "search": { "search": {string} // Search term "regex": {boolean} // Indicate if the search term should be treated as regex or not "smart": {boolean} // Flag to enable DataTables smart search "caseInsensitive": {boolean} // Case insensitive flag }, "columns" [ { "name": {string} // Column name (since 2.2) "visible": {boolean} // Column visibility "search": {} // Object containing column search information. Same structure as `search` above } ] } ```
Note that additional extensions can add extra information to this structure, or you may use `-init stateSaveParams` or `-event stateSaveParams` to add your own parameters. Also the information stored is type sensitive - that is, the data type of the data given by DataTables must be preserved. For example the `start` parameter must be a `-type number` data type.
This method is required only to store the data given to it. The `-init stateSaveParams` method is used to manipulate the data that is to actually be saved.
This callback works hand-in-hand with `-init stateLoadCallback`. This method saves the state while `-init stateSaveCallback` will load it from where this callback has saved it.
